awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Ultra-High-Efficiency Thermal Interface Materials Based on Self-Aligned Graphene Fillers
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project aims at demonstration of a revolutionary new thermal interface material (TIM) and innovative technology for TIM dispersion in industrial environments. Efficient thermal management is one of the most important requirements for further progress in semiconductor and communications technologies.  Growing densities of dissipated heat require new types of TIMs for heat removal from devices and chip packages. Strong enhancement of the thermal conductivity will be achieved via a novel functionalization of graphene flakes, which act as fillers in the TIM matrix. Graphene has the highest thermal conductivity of any known material. The project will lead to a better understanding of thermal transport in complex composites with graphene fillers and clarify the effect of nanoparticle surface functionalization on thermal coupling between the filler and matrix. The project's intellectual contributions will go beyond thermal management and impact other fields that unitize nanostructures for increased functionality and performance of advanced materials. It is expected that the graphene-enhanced TIMs to be developed will have the thermal conductivity values exceeding those of the commercially available TIMs by an order of magnitude. 

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project originates from the crucial importance of creating a more efficient TIM with the potential for a revolutionary advancement in thermal management. The proposed graphene-enhanced technology is expected to produce a transformative change in the $500 million TIM market.  Better heat removal enabled by functionalized graphene fillers will produce a lasting positive effect on the electronic and automotive industries, communications, photovoltaic energy generation, and aerospace and defense sectors. The proposed technology surpasses the competition by offering much stronger enhancement in thermal conductivity with a corresponding reduction in thermal resistance, and an industrially feasible TIM dispersion process. Finally, the availability of superior, cost-effective TIMs will help to preserve domestic technological leadership in the strategically important areas of information processing and communications.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_txt_cntn:
Normal 0     false false false  EN-US X-NONE X-NONE                                                                                                                                                                       
Efficient thermal management – removal of heat from active components of various devices – is currently considered to be one of the most important requirements for further progress in computers, mobile communications and renewable energy technologies. Thermal interface materials such as thermal greases and heat spreaders, which are applied between the heat generating devices and heat sinks, constitute the main approach for thermal management. The growing densities of dissipated heat require new types of thermal greases with increased thermal conductivity for device and chip packages. The demands for better thermal management are not limited to electronics. The power generation technologies for the photovoltaic solar cells also need efficient heat removal because the efficiency of energy conversion depends on the solar cell temperature. Commercially available thermal interface materials reveal insufficient thermal conductivity for heat removal for the new generation of electronic and optoelectronic devices. 
This project demonstrated the feasibility of a revolutionary new thermal interface material – thermal grease – with self-aligning graphene fillers and an innovative technology for the application of these thermal interface materials in the industrial processing environment. The order-of-magnitude enhancement of the thermal conductivity demonstrated in this project has been achieved via alignment of graphene flakes which act as fillers in the matrix material. Graphene – a single atomic plane of carbon atoms – has the highest thermal conductivity of all known materials. The inexpensive liquid-phase exfoliated graphene flakes have been functionalized to enable the alignment during the dispersion process. The research led to better understanding of thermal transport in complex composites with aligned fillers and clarified the effect of nanoparticle surface functionalization on thermal coupling between the filler and matrix. It also resulted in the development of a technology for functionalization of graphene fillers with a specific type of nanoparticles, which is essential for the filler alignment. 
The proof-of-concept experiments conducted with actual desktop computers and graphene-enhanced thermal greases demonstrated a significant reduction of the computer chip temperature (by more than 10 degrees) as compared to the best commercial thermal interface materials. The project results have potential for revolutionary advancements in thermal management. Better heat removal enabled with graphene self-aligning fillers can produce lasting positive effects on electronic industry, communications, photovoltaics, automotive industry, aerospace and defense technology. The advanced thermal interface materials with oriented graphene fillers allow one to lower the operational temperature of devices, achieve better reliability and improve energy efficiency. The project has also helped to increase participation of minorities in engineering.
